How I Spent 55 Days At Alagbon How I Spent 55 Days At Alagbon

Akintola Benson Oke, a masters degree holder in interna- tional relations from the University of Lagos, is a staff of Senator Bola Ahmed Tinubu, a prominent NADECO member now underground. After Tinubu's disappear- ance, Mr. Oke was arrested by security agents. He spent 55 days at the Alagbon Investigation Bureau. He nar- rated his experience to Duro Okunbaloye. Q: When and how were you arrested? A: I was arrested on Friday 16 September at Senator Bola Tinubu's guest house Lagos around 9.00 a.m. in the morning. Q: When and how were you arrested? A: I was arrested on Friday 16 September at Senator Bola Tinubu's guest house Lagos around 9.00 a.m. in the morning.

After about fifteen minutes of my arrest Senator Tinubu's cousin, Mr. Akeem Apatina came in and he too was promptly arrested by the police. About thirty minutes later, the policemen took us to Ejigbo, from where we were moved to Alagbon. We got to Alagbon around 6.00 p.m. After interrogat- ing us, they prepared our detention order, and put us in the cooler for 55 days. On the second day of our arrest, our houses were searched. The police called at my residence for a search. But nothing incriminating was found in my house as well as the houses of the other three people. From there, we started wondering what could have prompted our arrest and we did not get a clue until the third day when my father (Chief Samuel Agboola Akintan -the Ojomu of Idanreland) came to see the offic- ers handling our case at Alagbon. Q: Going by what you know of him would you say Senator Bola Tinubu has any link with the alleged bomb attempt in any way? A: As far as I know and as much as I can say as a close staff to him, I never got wind of anything like that. I can say this because he confides in me a great deal, even some other issues he partakes in, I get to know of them before he tells me; so the particular allegation in question I never got an inkling of it. A: Actually, Alagbon is a lion's den. Their food is very horrible. No mattresses, you just sleep on bare floor. A: Actually, Alagbon is a lion's den. Their food is very horrible. No mattresses, you just sleep on bare floor.

Also, there was no ventilation where we were detained. Everywhere was very dark, you can't see your mate with whom you are sharing the same room especially if you are coming from outside, so you need to have been in the dark for some hours before knowing if your partner is dead or sleeping. As to the relationship between myself and the security agents handling my case, I would say without any feat of contradiction that throughout my detention, our relationship was not too bad. Q: What other thing strikes you while in detention? Q: What other thing strikes you while in detention?

A: Traile one that strikes me most is that the detention itself is a state on its own where we have president, vice president and other officers In fact, all portfolios of government are there. Anytime one is detained, he has to pay his state fee, N2,000 only. One must obey all the officers and rules and regula- tions of the state. And one must be inaugu- rated in the state and say the national anthem of the Kalakuta republic named after Afro beat king Fela Anikulapo Kuti.
